Corporate policies in place for chemical safety:

CHEMICAL CONTROL PROGRAM

1.1    This Chemical Control Program is part of BioSafe Systems' Safety Manual. This program has been written to ensure that our manufacturing facilities follow regulations to ensure employees and contractors take all required safety precautions in usage, handling, and storage of chemicals.

1.2    This program is also present to minimize the potential for contamination of products, packaging, equipment and the surrounding environment.

2.1    Conformance and Compliance Standards

2.1.1    This Chemical Control Program complies with the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) Pocket Guide to Chemical Hazards Publication No. 2005-149, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) General Industry Standards 29CFR1910 Subpart Z and OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard 29CFR1910.119.

2.2    Definitions

2.2.1    Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) - any equipment worn or used by employees to mitigate the risk of exposure to chemicals that may harm them physically.  This may include safety glasses/goggles, face shields, chemical resistant gloves, chemical resistant boots, chemical resistant aprons/suits, and/or NIOSH approved respirators to protect the eyes, skin and respiratory system.

2.2.2    Engineering Controls - implement physical change to the workplace, which eliminates/reduces the hazard on the job/task which may include changing the process to minimize contact with hazardous materials, isolate or enclose the process, ventilation, eye wash stations and emergency showers.

2.2.3    Administrative and Work Practice Controls - establishing efficient processes or procedures such as job rotation assignments and adjusting work schedules to lessen exposure to hazardous chemicals.

2.2.4    Safety Data Sheets (SDS) [formerly known as Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS)] - a 16 section document unique to each chemical in the facility that is provided by the man

ufacturer of said chemical that lists the hazards associated with the chemical, the composition, safe handling, first aid instructions, regulatory information and various other pertinent information that is necessary for employees to review before beginning work with or around these chemicals.

3.1    General Safety



3.1.1    The safety department or assigned personnel at the manufacturing facility is ultimately responsible for training employees and contractors following the procedures for safe chemical handling on site and keeping records of such training.



3.1.2    BioSafe Systems' assigned safety personnel are responsible for providing SDSs, specifications, and Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the safe handling of chemicals, spill response, and operation of equipment.



3.1.3    It is the responsibility of the manufacturing facility to notify BioSafe Systems in the event of any spills, safety incidents or equipment failures as soon as possible.            

4.1    Purchasing

4.1.1    BioSafe Systems purchases and schedules shipments of chemicals to each facility based on projected usage and current orders.  Only approved suppliers and carriers may be used to purchase and deliver chemicals to each facility.

4.1.2    Facilities are notified when purchase orders are placed and deliveries are scheduled.

4.2    Preventing Unauthorized Usage    

4.2.1    Security measures are required to be in place and followed for the receipt and storage of chemicals, including entrances that are locked at all times when not in use, carriers must provide the proper paperwork and seals, exterior lighting, and fencing around critical areas.

4.2.2    The facility is responsible for ensuring that only authorized employees have access to batching systems and the bulk storage tanks.

4.2.3    The removal of chemicals by any personnel from the premises is forbidden.

4.2.4    The Department of Homeland Security regulates the security, storage, receiving, shipping and handling of any Chemicals of Interest (COI) present

at the facility.

4.3    Storage and Handling

4.3.1    Only competent and authorized personnel at the manufacturing facilities are permitted access to the batching system that is used to formulate BioSafe Systems' products.

4.3.2    Only approved equipment may be used to store chemicals. Certified chemically compatible containers, Original manufacturer's containers, Passivated stainless steel tanks and pipes.

4.3.3    Employees are trained in using the proper chemicals for the formulas, following blending instructions, reading labels and SDSs for storage temperatures/conditions, proper PPE, first aid and chemical composition.



4.4    Protection from Contamination    

4.4.1    Storing chemicals in designated areas, away from food, ingredients, equipment, packaging and processing aids etc.

4.4.2    Ensuring chemicals are stored in closed containers when not in use; that they can be clearly identified (including those that have been decanted into spray bottles and dispensers); ensuring any containers and equipment used for measuring, storing and pouring chemicals can be clearly identified as for that purpose only (e.g. label 'For Chemicals Only').

4.4.3    Ensuring unused chemicals are disposed of appropriately (e.g. by a chemical waste company, discharge permit after neutralization); and ensuring appropriate cleaning is done after chemical use.

4.5    Controlling Hazards    

    4.5.1    Risk Assessments

    4.5.1.1    Identifying the Hazard - type and nature of health effects caused by chemicals by studying the scientific literature and assessing field and laboratory data collected by NIOSH. Hazard identification is the first stage of the risk assessment. In the hazard identification stage, the data on health effects are gathered and analyzed to improve understanding of what health effects are or could be caused by the chemical and which health effects should be evaluated in the assessment of the exposure-response relationship.

    4.5.1.2    Assessing Workplace Exposure - after identifying a hazard, asse

ss the nature of the workplace exposure and the affected worker population. The amount and degree of occupational exposure is assessed in this step, sometimes through NIOSH Health Hazard Evaluations or epidemiological investigations. The most common routes of chemical exposure in the workplace are inhalation and skin contact.

    4.5.1.3    Assessing the Exposure-Response Relationship - exploring the relationship between current or past exposure levels of the hazardous material to assess the opportunity for, and seriousness of, health effects from that exposure. The exposure-response relationship between a hazardous substance and adverse health effects is typically described using statistical models. These models account for factors that may affect the accuracy of exposure-response estimates, such as data quality or the presence of other risk factors.

    4.5.1.4    Characterizing Workplace Risk - Information gathered from the three previous steps is distilled to form a clear picture of the nature and magnitude of the work-related risks. This risk characterization is used to inform risk management decisions.

    4.5.2    Engineering Controls

    4.5.2.1    Engineering controls protect workers by removing hazardous conditions or by placing a barrier between the worker and the hazard. Examples include local exhaust ventilation to capture and remove airborne emissions or machine guards to shield the worker. Well-designed engineering controls can be highly effective in protecting workers and will typically be independent of worker interactions. They typically do not interfere with worker productivity or personal comfort and make the work easier to perform rather than more difficult. 

    4.5.3    Personal Protective Equipment

    4.5.3.1    Eye Safety - the appropriate eye protection must be worn during tasks where the risk of chemical splashes, chemical spills or other contaminants may make contact with the eyes. Light duty tasks may only require safety glasses, such as running an automated batchin

g system, whereas dispensing chemicals would require safety goggles that cover the entire eye area, or even a face shield for comprehensive protection.

    4.5.3.2    Skin Protection - the appropriate skin protection clothing must be worn during tasks where the risk of chemical splashes or chemical spills may make direct or indirect contact with the skin. Light duty tasks may only require chemical resistant gloves (latex, nitrile or neoprene) and long sleeves. Dispensing chemicals or filling containers would require gloves, long sleeves, pants, socks and chemical resistant boots for comprehensive protection.

    4.5.3.3    Respiratory protection - NIOSH approved respirators are recommended when cleaning up spills or in situations where vapors can irritate an employee's respiratory tract.  Full face respirators with P100 Organic Vapor/Acid Gas cartridges are highly recommended for this purpose.

4.6    Monitoring Requirements    

4.6.1    Routine audits should be conducted of storage areas, chemical containers, labeling and chemical disposition.

4.6.2    A chemical inventory should be maintained of chemicals in stock, particularly hazardous chemicals.

5.1    Corrective Actions 

5.1.1    Define the extent of the problem (i.e. what has happened, why it happened, and how much and which (if any) product has been affected).

5.1.2    Restore control (i.e. the action needed immediately to stop more product becoming affected and to fix problem).

5.1.3    Handling of affected things including ingredients, packaging, products, contaminated equipment, etc. (e.g. preventing any suspect product from being released; following your procedure for dealing with non-conforming product.

5.1.4    Preventing re-occurrence (e.g. using information gained from the problem to identify better ways to do things; develop better procedures; improve the checking systems; provide better staff training, etc.).            

6.1     Documentation and Recordkeeping

6.1.1    Records must be kept of any inspections, incidents, training, shipping a

nd receiving, batching and quality control checks.

6.1.2    Records must be kept for a minimum of 3 years, either electronically or paper.  Paper documents must be stored in a climate-controlled environment where the risk of contamination by chemicals is minimal.



EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN / RESUMPTION OF OPERATIONS



Utility Outages - Electrical, Internet / Phone, Water: System disruption: production, reporting, communication, security.    Unable to resume most production activities until utility is restored. Physical security systems still in place. 1. Ensure facility is physically secure and routinely monitor is power is out for extended periods of time.

2. Notification to local law enforcement for routine patrols due to storage of COI if employees are not able to routinely monitor conditions.

3. Notification to DHS if security measures near the COI are compromised due to outages.



Tornado, Hurricane, Severe Storm: Electrical outage (see above), wind damage, flooding, impassable roadways. Unable to resume most production activities until power is restored. Physical security systems may be comprised.

1. Shelter in place for imminent danger, evacuate with enough warning.

2. Ensure facility is physically secure and routinely monitor is power is out for extended periods of time.

3. Notification to local law enforcement for routine patrols due to storage of COI if employees are not able to routinely monitor conditions.

4. Notification to DHS if security measures near the COI are compromised due to outages.



Aircraft Crash: Widespread severe building damage and electrical outage (see above), injuries probable, public concern, impassable roadways. Unable to resume most production activities until power is restored. Physical security systems may be comprised. Storage of COI may be comprised.    

1. Evacuate the building of all personnel.

2. Notify DHS of incident immediately and secure COI if possible, emergency response is critical for probable release of COI.

3. Acti

vate crisis management plan.



Fire: Possible injuries, building damage, product damage, explosion in certain conditions, public concern. Facility activities disrupted. COI in danger of creating explosive hazard. Public relations exposure. Physical and electrical security systems may be comprised.

1. Evacuate the building of all personnel.

2. Immediately notify first responders and ensure they are aware of the risks of the COI, other chemicals and product stored inside the building.

3. Activate crisis management plan. Media response probable.

4. Secure COI if possible and notify law enforcement for routine patrols if business is interrupted.



Hazardous Chemical Release: Probable injuries, public concern. Facility activities disrupted. Regulatory penalties possible. Public relations exposure.    

1. Evacuate the building of all personnel.

2. Activate crisis management plan for releases over the threshold quantity.

3. Notification to government authorities, first responders and CHEMTREC concerning release.

4. Media response probable.



Terrorist Threat / Intruders / Civil Disturbance: Possible injuries, building damage, security comprised, public concern. General or serious distractions with civil disturbances. Facility activities may be disrupted. Physical security may be comprised. Public relations exposure. Storage of COI may be comprised.

1. Activate crisis management plan to investigate validity of threats.

2. Local law enforcement response is required to protect the integrity of the building, employees and storage of the COI.

3. Notify DHS of incident immediately and secure COI if possible. Media response probable.



Also on file: Chemical Spill Response Program, Hazard Communication Program, Cyber Security Plan, Department of Homeland Security Plan, 

 

Description of the facility:

The production facility manufactures peracetic acid through a chemical reaction between water, hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid.  The regulated substance for the RMP

is peracetic acid. Hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid are also subject to other EPA regulations not included in the RMP.  Over the course of a year, approximately 1,000,000 pounds of varying concentrations of peracetic acid will be produced and shipped out of the facility.

The facility is regulated by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) which monitors the storage of chemicals at the facility.  Because of this, security measures are very high at the facility in preventing unauthorized access to the storage area, the production area, and cyber security attacks.

The facility is not currently under the OSHA PSM rule, but there are plans to increase the concentration of a chemical that would put the facility into PSM.  Currently, the facility operates as though it is under the PSM rule for additional safety.

 

The five-year accident history:

There have been no accidental releases at this facility in the last five years.

 

ERP Elements:

The facility's emergency response plan has been reviewed by the local fire department and the state.  Personnel working at the facility are trained in the plan as well as receiving other relevant training in hazardous material handling.  In addition, 3 managers in the company, including one at the facility, are trained to HAZWOPER standards.  The facility is equipped with multiple redundant alarms and intruder monitoring systems.

 

Upcoming events:

Continuous improvement on training for employees, planned upgrades to equipment as capital expenditures over the next several years, planned upgrades to current technology for closer monitoring of the facility remotely.
